channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My husband thinks being cautious leads to bad things happening
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My husband thinks being cautious leads to bad things happening

item.title: Analysis: The very worst sports decisions of 2024, from Scottie Scheffler’s arrest to Jordan Chiles’s medal controversy
item.description: Moments of splendor were accompanied by, well, less splendid narratives. Teams that chose poorly. Stars who stumbled. That whole Jake Paul thing. Thus, in what is now an annual tradition, here is our non-comprehensive list of some of the most regrettable moments of the year.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Putin apologizes to Azerbaijan’s leader after plane crash for ‘the tragic incident’ in Russian airspace
item.description: The Kremlin statement Saturday did not take responsibility for downing the Azerbaijan Airlines flight that was due to land in Russia but crashed in Kazakhstan on Christmas Day. The White House said Friday that evidence suggests the plane was brought down by Russia, resulting in the deaths of 38 people; 29 survived.

item.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to delay the TikTok ban to allow him time to negotiate the popular app’s future once he’s in office
item.description: The president-elect asked the court to push back a Jan. 19 deadline requiring the platform's Chinese owner ByteDance to divest from the app.

item.title: How did Loudoun Gateway become the loneliest Metro stop?
item.description: The second-to-last station on the Silver Line was envisioned as a thriving mixed-use stop. Instead, it’s anything but.

item.title: Greg Gumbel dies at 78. The longtime sportscaster was known for his work during March Madness and on NFL broadcasts.
item.description: Gumbel’s family on Friday confirmed his death in a statement, which was released by CBS. Gumbel — who suffered from cancer, according to the family’s statement — was well-known to sports fans, particularly when Selection Sunday kicked off the NCAA men’s basketball tournament. He also was the first African American announcer to call play-by-play of a Super Bowl.

item.title: U.S. homelessness soared 18 percent to a record level amid a surge in home prices and a decline in covid-era assistance
item.description: An annual federal assessment estimated 771,480 people were living in shelters, temporary housing or outside in tents or cars based on a single night in January 2024.

item.title: White House says there are ‘indications’ Azerbaijani airliner was brought down by Russia this week
item.description: Thirty-eight people were killed in the crash. National Security Council spokesman John Kirby says the U.S. government has initial indications, in addition to widely circulating images of the wreckage, suggesting the Baku-Grozny flight was impacted by air defense fire.

item.title: Musk clashes with far right over skilled-worker visa program
item.description: The online rift over the need for H-1B visas — a skilled-worker immigration program that has long been a lifeblood for Silicon Valley — signifies a potential rift between Trump’s core nationalist base and technology executives who have come to support him.

item.title: Seven columnists posed these big questions when the year began. Here’s where they landed.
item.description: Seven Post columnists answer the questions they posed when the year began.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Israeli strikes. Trump supporters. Plane crash. Western storms. Holiday spending. Hudson Meek. Missing packages. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Sea level rise in the U.S. South is blowing past expectations. Here’s what’s driving it.
item.description: A large increase in sea levels is causing severe flooding across the region. At Georgia's Fort Pulaski, sea levels have risen 7 inches since 2010. Scientists have pinpointed the factors behind the sudden surge.

item.title: Richard Parsons has died at 76. He was a leading executive at Time Warner and Citi.
item.description: Parsons charted an impressive trajectory from his middle-class childhood in Queens to the top of his law school class in Albany, New York, to his place as one of the few African Americans in the highest echelons of U.S. business. He provided a steadying force for media and financial institutions in moments of boardroom and market turbulence.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: She attacks her sister’s parenting but accepts her room discount
item.description: Carolyn Hax: She attacks her sister’s parenting but accepts her room discount

item.title: Israeli strikes hit an airport in Yemen’s capital as the WHO chief and other U.N. officials were about to board a plane
item.description:
Israel said Thursday it was targeting Houthi militant infrastructure across Yemen. The aerial bombardment included strikes on the international airport in Sanaa, where the head of the World Health Organization, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was about to board his flight when the missiles hit.
“One of our plane’s crew members was injured,” Tedros said in a post on X, adding that the runway and air traffic control tower were also damaged.

item.title: These low-income Trump voters hope he doesn’t slash their benefits
item.description: Voters in the struggling Pennsylvania city of New Castle backed Donald Trump, hoping he’d curb inflation. But the incoming president will be under pressure to cut spending.

item.title: Happy Hanukkah! Play today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: Trump’s border plans. Journalist deaths. King Charles. Return to office. Yoshio Taniguchi. NFL and Beyoncé. Otters. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Can you find all 50 sentient Christmas trees? Play our festive search game.
item.description: Sweet pine o’ mine! It’s time to pick a tree — 50 of them, in fact.

item.title: Asking Eric: I want to stop giving my grandkids Christmas gifts
item.description: Asking Eric: I want to stop giving my grandkids Christmas gifts

item.title: Inside the stunning fight to bring the Commanders back to D.C.: Fighter jets and the mayor’s promise to a nemesis
item.description: The last-minute negotiations involved transferring fighter jets to Maryland and promising support for the National Park Service to one of D.C.’s biggest critics on Capitol Hill. It all led to the Senate’s 1:15 a.m. passage of a bill that will allow D.C. to redevelop the land surrounding the defunct RFK football stadium, one of this generation’s greatest economic development opportunities in Washington.

item.title: Merry Christmas! Unwrap today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: The hidden science swirling in ‘The Starry Night’
item.description: Vincent van Gogh’s painting has long been admired for its artistic value, but the famous painting from the Dutch post-impressionist has sparked fascination and controversy among physicists over the science behind the whirling brushstrokes.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Wife buys her own gift and instructs spouse to wrap it
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Wife buys her own gift and instructs spouse to wrap it

item.title: Want more time with friends? Here are some data-backed tips to help.
item.description: What the data can teach us about friendship — and how to be less alone.

item.title: I have Stage 4 lung cancer in my 20s, a Post journalist writes. These survivors give her hope.
item.description: These survivors, or “cancer thrivers” as some prefer to say, helped show the author that metastatic cancer is not always a death sentence.

item.title: Merry Christmas Eve! Play today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points!

item.title: Matt Gaetz. Trump eyes Greenland. Luigi Mangione. Wharf collapse. IRS payouts. Starbucks strike. Bob Dylan. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The new rules of insuring your home in the age of climate change
item.description: Insurance premiums are soaring as the damage from wildfires, flooding and severe storms mounts. Here are ways to find plans that protect your home and safeguard your future amid intensifying climate risk.

item.title: Biden commuted the sentences of 37 death row inmates. Wesley Lowery writes about two — one proclaimed innocence, the other remorse.
item.description: Biden just commuted the sentences of 37 death row inmates. Let me tell you about two of these men.

item.title: To save itself, ‘Sesame Street’ is focusing less on Bert, Ernie and Big Bird
item.description: Come behind the scenes as the iconic children’s show creates its upcoming season, which focuses on the emotional well-being of children. With a financially critical HBO deal ending, “Sesame Street” is searching for a new home and preparing big changes, including a new format and smaller roles for some classic Muppets.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Taking gift rules personally after sister’s Muslim conversion
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Taking gift rules personally after sister’s Muslim conversion

item.title: D.C. officer is found guilty of leaking to Proud Boys leader before Jan. 6, 2021, attack on U.S. Capitol
item.description: Lt. Shane Lamond was convicted in a case that accused him of feeding information to the Proud Boys and lying about it.

item.title: House Ethics report concludes Matt Gaetz regularly paid for sex, including a payment to an underage girl
item.description:
The bipartisan panel released a report Monday detailing the findings of its long-running investigation into the former Florida congressman, who resigned his House seat shortly after President-elect Donald Trump tapped him to be attorney general. Gaetz later withdrew his bid.
The report also accused Gaetz of possessing illegal drugs and accepting lavish gifts while serving in Congress.

item.title: Get into the holiday spirit with today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Death row. Trump and Musk. Germany attack. Boarding schools. Blake Lively. Robotaxis. Skinny Christmas trees. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Biden commutes the death sentences of most federal inmates before Trump takes office
item.description: The president changed the sentences of 37 of the 40 prisoners on death row to life without parole, saying he was convinced “that we must stop the use of the death penalty at the federal level.” The incoming Trump administration is widely expected to restart executions. Three others, involved in cases of “terrorism and hate-motivated mass murder,” still face execution.

item.title: In deep-red Arizona, ‘a genuinely good person’ tries not to surrender to anger and resentment after Trump’s win
item.description: Cydni Irving finds herself increasingly surrounded by polarization in the face of poverty and need. In the aftermath of the election, a startling thought leads her to ask what kind of person she wants to be.

item.title: The number of 401(k) millionaires hit a new record — and this time, millennials joined the club. Here’s how they did it.
item.description: The number of 401(k) millionaires hit a new record — and this time, millennials joined the club. Here’s how they did it.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: More than 3,100 students died at U.S. schools built to crush Native American cultures, Post investigation finds
item.description: The year-long investigation found more than three times the number of student deaths as documented by the U.S. government over 150 years. The Post found records of more than 800 students buried in cemeteries at or near former schools created by the U.S. government to assimilate Native American children into White society.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Rickey Henderson dies at 65. The Hall of Fame baseball player is widely considered the greatest leadoff hitter of all-time.
item.description: Henderson's family announced Saturday in a statement released by the Athletics that Henderson had died, without citing a cause. Over a remarkable career that spanned 25 seasons from 1979 to 2003, Henderson was one of the sport's most colorful personalities. He is MLB's all-time leader in both runs scored and stolen bases.

item.title: Assad’s grip on power was more tenuous than it appeared. How rebels overcame years of bloody stalemate to topple his regime.
item.description: The story of Syria’s rebellion — told by rebels, Assad’s relatives, diplomats and others — reveals an insurgent offensive years in the making and a dictator, undone by a collapsing army and reluctant allies, in denial to the end. “Damascus is strong,” Assad told relatives, right until he fled.

item.title: The District now has a realistic option for Commanders’ stadium at the old RFK site after political Hail Mary
item.description: In a stunning, last-second twist, Congress passed federal legislation early Saturday to allow D.C. to redevelop the RFK Stadium site and potentially bring the Washington Commanders back to the city. The bill extends the National Park Service’s lease to the city for 99 years and allows for mixed-use development, including commercial, residential and a stadium.

item.title: What’s the secret to living — and aging — well? Get a 12-week newsletter from bestselling author Anne Lamott to find out.
item.description: Sign up for A User's Guide to Aging from The Washington Post

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: German Christmas market attack toll rises to at least five dead and over 200 injured, officials say
item.description: Many of the injured were in critical condition, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said. The suspect, a 50-year-old Saudi doctor who arrived in Germany in 2006, had expressed anti-Islam views and described himself as a Saudi dissident, according to a German official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss an open investigation.
